In a bid to tackle the degrading climate conditions, the new age research in catalysis is predominantly focused on sustainable technologies associated with renewable energy conversion and environment purification. One of the primary motivations for the research in catalysis is the use of low-cost, earth-abundant materials that can fulfill the scale-up needs of respective technologies. Cobalt (Co) based catalysts have been an indispensable part of almost all areas of catalysis and they are often looked at as low-cost substitutes for precious metal-based catalysts. In the context of energy and environmental applications, Co-based catalysts are more commonly used for reactions such as hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), oxygen evolution reaction (OER), hydrolysis of chemical hydrides, CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) and advanced oxidation processes (AOPs). Co-based catalysts are interesting compounds as Co plays a diverse role in facilitating different reactions. This review provides a brief account of the significance of Co-based catalysts and elaborates their advancement in each of the above-mentioned applications and presents future research directions with the use of Co-based catalysts. An in-depth analysis to gain a deeper understanding of the Co-based systems is highly desired to promote breakthroughs in catalysis. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Cobalt catalyst Hydrogen evolution reaction Oxygen evolution reaction CO2 reduction Environment purification Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Energy and environment are certainly amongst the topmost global challenges of the present era. The oil-based energy sources are on the verge of extinction and may result in a huge energy scarcity in the coming future [1,2]. Also, the prevalent use of fossil fuels has contributed to the humongous amounts of greenhouse gas additions to the atmosphere. The continuous rise of such greenhouse gases and the consequent environmental degradation have led to several catastrophic events all over the globe. Moreover, the present geo-political crisis has resulted in further shortage of fossil-based energy sources. To mitigate the adverse effects of changing climate and find alternative energy sources, several strategies have been explored. In the context of clean energy, hydrogen (H2) has emerged as one of the most ideal renewable energy vectors [3–5]. H2 can be used as a fuel for transportation, for storing energy from intermittent renewables and also as a feedstock for industries [5]. The key chemical reactions for the generation of hydrogen are electrolysis of water (hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) [4,6–8], oxygen evolution reaction (OER) [8–11]), oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and hydrolysis of chemical hydrides [12–14]. In addition to using H2 as an energy vector, the other strategy is to recycle the by-products evolved from the current energy set-up by directly trapping the CO2 from the atmosphere (or from the point of emission) and convert it into usable chemical fuels (syngas, alcohols, etc.) using CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) [15–17]. This is not only a vital reaction to regenerate usable fuels but is also a crucial one to slash the carbon content in the atmosphere. In the context of environmental issues, the contamination of water streams by industrial waste effluents is a big concern. The aqueous waste from various industries (such as chemical industries) contains several toxic organic impurities (in addition to inorganic ones) which when discarded directly into the natural water streams present adverse effects on the aquatic life and consequently impact the human food chain as well [18,19]. There are several well-established methods to treat wastewater and get rid of inorganic pollutants. However, not many low-cost methods are well-suited to treat the organic pollutants from the industrial wastewater. One of the most important reactions (processes) that has intrigued the research community is advanced oxidation process (AOP) [20,21]. AOPs involving sulfate and hydroxyl radicals are simple and sustainable methods that can be employed to effectively treat industrial wastewater and prevent environmental degradation. All the above-mentioned reactions are essentially driven by catalysts. The key role of a catalyst is to increase the rate of reaction without altering the actual reaction. Commercially, Pt-group metals (PGMs) such as Pt, Pd, Rh, Ru, Ir, etc. are known to be the most active catalysts [22,23]. However, the high cost and relatively low earth-abundance of these elements prevent their long-term use on a larger scale [8,24]. To overcome the industrial reliance on these PGM-based catalysts, the research community has been obsessed with the search for low-cost, earth-abundant metal catalysts for many decades. In this bid, transition metal-based catalysts have been one of the most widely researched materials that provide great promise to replace the PGM-based catalysts [25–28]. Among transition metals, cobalt (Co) is one of the most widely used and researched elements in almost all fields of catalysis. In the last few decades, Co-based catalysts have been predominantly used in energy and environmental sectors to such an extent that the European Union added it to the list of critical raw materials. The exceptional catalytic activity of Co can be ascribed primarily to its partially filled d orbital (3d7). In addition to its elemental form, Co exists in Co2+ and Co3+ oxidation states which makes it easier to form composites by either combining with other elements or supports. Likewise, numerous nanostructures of Co and Co-based compounds are explored with an aim to increase the effective catalytic surface area, expose more number of active sites and selectively expose the most active catalytic centers. There have been a few reviews focused on specific applications of Co-based catalysts [28–31] but to the best of our knowledge, there has hardly been a comprehensive review that unanimously covers the key energy and environment-related catalytic reactions. This review is an attempt to fill this gap and highlight the significance of Co-based catalysts in such reactions. To accomplish this, the review discusses the origin of the catalytic activity in different Co-based compounds. Furthermore, the catalytic reactions such as HER, OER, hydrolysis of chemical hydrides, CO2RR and advanced oxidation processes (AOPs) are briefly discussed and the recent scientific/technological advancement in each of these reactions is presented comprehensively. A short summary and future outlook are included towards the end of the review that informs the readers about the possible future opportunities with Co-based catalysts. 2 Origin of catalytic activity in Cobalt First-row transition metals like Fe, Co and Ni have the ability, to exchange electrons with external species [32], to be present in a variety of oxidation states [33], to easily interchange between the oxidation states [34], and to act as a source or sink for electrons [35]. All these chemical properties make them active catalysts. Amongst them, cobalt with 3 unfilled d-orbitals, as compared to 2 for Ni and 4 for Fe, provides an optimum interaction with chemical species arriving on the surface by forming bonds that are neither too strong nor too weak to aid the absorption and desorption of reactant and product. Structural defects like vacancies located in the crystal lattice near the surface makes these cobalt sites even more catalytically active due to uncoordinated nature of these sites [36]. In the case of oxides, hematite (Fe2O3) and NiO are the most stable form of Fe and Ni oxides with a single Fe3+ and Ni2+ state, while the most stable cobalt oxide (Co3O4) is composed of two oxidation states Co2+ and Co3+ whose quantity can be altered by just employing the redox condition [37]. This particular property of cobalt is ideal for forming complexes with the reagent, where if the transition state of reaction demands electrons, cobalt in the complexes undergo redox reactions (Co2+ to Co3+) to supply electrons. On the other hand, if there is an excess build-up of electrons during the reaction, Co with dual oxidation states can hold this surplus electron density to facilitate the proceeding of the reaction [38]. Thus, cobalt species can react to form more than one ion to exhibit catalysis in the solution. Co3O4 with spinel structure also has the capability to show multiple facets such as (110), (100), and (111) on the surface to drive the reactions with different activity due to diverse electronic and geometric structures [39]. The semiconductor nature of Co3O4 with a bandgap of 1.8–2.2 eV also makes it suitable for photocatalysis applications under visible light [40]. Due to all these unique properties ( Fig. 1), 90% of cobalt is being used as the catalyst in different industries, mainly in two major applications: (1) desulphurization reactions to remove sulfur moieties from natural gas and refined petroleum products, (2) Fischer-Tropsch process to produce synthetic fuels from the natural gas. About 25,000 kg of sulfur oxide (SOx) emission is reduced by using 1 kg of cobalt as a catalyst. By implementing cobalt catalyst for recycling plastic also provides a green solution towards the ever-growing waste sludge of plastic. In chemical industries, the production of aldehydes from alkenes in OXO-reaction is possible only in presence of a cobalt catalyst. The crosslinking of oil-based paint is accelerated by the cobalt catalyst, thus playing a vital role in the drying of paints for the ink and pigments industries. Other forms of cobalt oxides like CoO and Co2O3 are also very active for catalytic reactions owing to the abundant amount of Co2+ species but their unstable nature and inability to regenerate Co2+ on the surface makes these oxides unsuitable for practical applications. Mixed-metal cobalt oxide offers multifunctionality during the catalytic reactions by electronic interaction between metal and cobalt [41]. For example, cobalt ferrite (CoFe2O4) shows highly improved magnetic properties that makes them easily recoverable from the reaction mixture [42]. The entanglement between Fe and Co caused by electronic interaction is able to suppress the cobalt leaching during the reaction in harsh conditions [42]. Along with these beneficial properties, CoFe2O4 with Co2+ species is highly active and selective for various catalytic reactions. Similarly, Co-based perovskite materials (SrCoO3 and LaCoO3) present the prospect to incorporate 90% of the metallic foreign elements from the periodic table [43]. This can cause variation in atomic distances, distortion in the unit cell, induces cationic or anionic vacancies within the lattice, or stabilizes multiple oxidation states, giving rise to a variety of structures with the tunable active sites on the surface. Cobalt-based layered double hydroxide (LDH) materials with 2D layered structure offers exposure to a large number of metal sites that are unsaturated due to the defects induced by the exfoliation technique [44]. The oxygen vacancies in LDH also provides the flexibility to tune the electronic configuration of these metal sites as per the requirement of the specific reaction mechanism [45]. As compared to metals and oxides, non-oxide cobalt-based compounds such as Co-borides, Co-carbides, Co-phosphides, Co-nitrides and Co-chalcogenides induce highly stimulating properties for catalytic reaction by modulating the electronic configuration of cobalt-sites. In the case of cobalt boride (Co-B) catalyst, an unexpected behavior is observed in an amorphous structure where even with higher electronegativity of B, the electrons are shifted away from B towards Co [14,46]. This makes metallic sites enriched with electrons, which is a prerequisite for the electrochemical-based catalytic reactions. Unlike Co-B, the electrons are transferred from Co to P in cobalt-phosphide compounds to significantly improve the adsorption of the nucleophilic compound on the metal sites by acting as Lewis acid sites [47]. 2D structure with exposed catalytically active edges makes Co-chalcogenides (CoS2 and CoSe2) potential catalytic materials with superior electronic properties. In a similar context, Co-C composite improves the electrical conducting properties by involving carbon [48]. All these tunable properties of Co-based compounds are mainly attributed to the electronic configuration of the cobalt element having a partially filled d-orbital with electrons that are readily available for the interaction with the exterior components. The above-mentioned promoting properties have designated cobalt as a versatile catalyst for various applications such as OER, ORR, HER, CO2-RR, H2 production from chemical hydrides, removal of organic pollutants from water by photocatalysis, etc. Nevertheless, the specific role played by cobalt for these applications still needs to be deeply explored. Advances in computational methods and experimental techniques, mainly operando measurements, have facilitated up to certain extent to connect the missing links between the improved activity and the unique features of cobalt. For instance, in electrochemical OER/ORR, the active species of Co with higher oxidation states (COOOH and CoO2) are formed initially on the surface during the reaction, as depicted by in-situ experiments, to offer high activity [49]. Moreover, Co is found to be more favorable for the formation of these species at lower potential than Ni and Fe, and reason for the same was found by in-situ experiments which suggest that for OER/ORR the starting structure of the Co species determines the final outcome [49]. As in the case of Co3O4 spinel oxide, in-situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) and Raman measurements depicted that the mixed states of Co2+ and Co3+ transform into higher oxidation states of CoOOH and CoO2 on the surface upon increasing the applied voltage [50]. Similar measurements also identified that non-spinel Co oxides form a larger quantity of these active species for OER than spinel Co oxides [51,52]. This finding was well correlated with the computational studies where the activation energy barrier for the formation of CoOOH is lower for non-spinel than spinel Co oxides [49]. Moreover, operando studies also showed that tetrahedral sites (Co2+) gets oxidized easily into higher oxidation states (Co3+ and Co4+) with increasing potential, but octahedral sites (Co3+) remained unchanged in the applied potential range [53]. The introduction of oxygen vacancies can tune electrochemical properties of cobalt oxides. Compared with pristine Co3O4, the defective structure with oxygen vacancies facilitate the formation of active CoOOH species as suggested by in-situ Co K edge XAS [50]. In-situ studies also suggest that non-metal-based Co compound act as a ‘pre-catalyst’ to form active species for OER/ORR [54,55]. Similarly, for HER the formation of electron-enriched Co sites is noticed in operando XAS measurements when the cathodic potential is applied to non-oxide Co-compounds [30]. This exclusive property of Co-compound to switch its capability for both OER and HER by just varying the redox potential gives it the bifunctional nature for overall water splitting. Co-based catalysts are also found to be very effective in electro-reduction of CO2 to CO with appreciable selectivity and activity [31,56]. Multiple oxidation states of Co are found to be highly beneficial for CO2RR with the transition from Co2+ to Co+ acting as the intermediate state for CO2 reduction [31]. In comparison to other non-noble counterparts, Co demonstrated enhanced CO2 adsorption due to the d-band close to the Fermi level [57]. In photocatalytic CO2 reduction, reduced cobalt oxide displays the best conversion rate with Co-Ox asymmetrical unsaturated sites acting as the catalytic sites for CO2 activation, as confirmed by in-situ XAS, while Co metal sites offer the traps for electrons to facilitate electron-hole separation [57]. The electronic configuration over Co also plays a vital role in stabilizing the major intermediates in CO2 reduction [31,58]. This interchangeable cobalt oxidation states are favorable for the generation of oxidation species like sulphate ( SO 4 ⦁ − ) and hydroxyl ( HO ⦁ ) radicals for photocatalytic removal of organic pollutants from water. Using all these properties, how cobalt-based catalysts are effective for energy and environment oriented catalytic reactions are reviewed in the following sections. 3 Co-based catalysts in energy applications 3.1 Hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) With the rising prominence of hydrogen in zero-carbon energy strategies, HER has become a very important catalytic reaction [6,59]. In a water electrolysis cell, HER takes place on the cathode where electrons served by the catalyst are responsible for reduction of electrolytic species to produce gaseous hydrogen. HER in different pH solutions is represented in Eqs. 1–2: (1) In acidic solution, 2 H+ (aq) + 2e-→H2(g) (2) In alkaline solution, 2 H2O(aq) + 2e-→H2(g) + 2OH- (aq) Being a reduction reaction, it is customary that the catalyst surface (acting as cathode) must be rich with electrons to facilitate HER. However, excess electron density at the catalytic site does not guarantee better HER rates. The bonding strength between the catalyst surface and hydrogen is very crucial as that determines the rate of adsorption and desorption (Sebatier principle) [60]. This characteristic is represented by the empirical Volcano plot [61] which suggests that Co metal does not exhibit the most ideal H bonding strength when compared to noble-metals (Pt, Ir, Rh, etc.) that lie at the peak of the Volcano plot. However, this shortcoming is compensated by forming Co compounds that exhibit HER rates on par with that of the noble-metal catalysts. The key metric used to quantify the HER performance of a catalyst is the overpotential, which is generally defined as the additional potential required by a catalyst above the thermodynamic value, to achieve a certain current density [62]. The water electrolysis community has somehow been obsessed with the current density value of 10 mA/cm2 which was defined to be the value relevant to a solar water splitting system with ∼12% solar to hydrogen efficiency [59]. However, for electrolysis systems, commercially relevant current densities are much higher (500–1000 mA/cm2) and hence in recent studies, the electrocatalysts are subjected to such higher values [63]. The other key parameter is the turn over frequency (TOF) that estimates the catalytic activity per site and is a better metric to gauge the intrinsic performance of the catalyst. Additionally, the stability and recycling ability of the catalysts are other factors that are considered while defining the performance of an electrocatalyst [62]. In the subsequent sections, the large number of Co-based HER catalysts are classified based on the category of elements to which they are bonded. The main categories of elements considered here are non-metals (N, P, C, S, Se), metalloids (B, Te) and noble metals (Pt, Ru, Pd, Ir). 3.1.1 Non-metal based Co-compounds Co-N-carbides: Carbonaceous materials are known to possess high electronic conductivity, which is highly advantageous in electron mediated reactions such as HER. Another major advantage of carbonaceous materials is their superior stability in both acidic and alkali electrolytes for HER [64]. Owing to these significant advantages, a large number of Co-carbide composites have been reported for HER [64–69]. In a recent report, Co nanoparticles (NPs) encapsulated with N-doped carbon nanotubes was presented with a HER activity very close to that of Pt/C, as it achieves the benchmark current density of 10 mA/cm2 at a minimal overpotential of 7 mV in acidic solutions [64]. The catalyst was active and stable in alkali electrolytes as well. The unique morphology of the catalyst ( Fig. 2 a-d) not only protects the Co atom from corrosion but also alters the charge density of the surface shell to optimize the hydrogen adsorption/desorption kinetics, thus resulting in higher stability and HER rates. Similarly, cobalt-embedded nitrogen-rich CNTs (Co-NRCNTs) were reported by Asefa et al. as a highly active HER catalyst in acidic, neutral and alkali media [65]. The authors compared the electrocatalytic rates with that of Fe and Ni embedded catalysts and they observed that the HER rate varied as Fe-NRCNTs < Ni-NRCNTs < Co-NRCNTs, suggesting that Co had higher contribution towards the HER performance. The authors proposed that the presence of lone pair electrons in N atoms render them more favorable for interaction with reactants as compared to C atoms. However, N being more electronegative, the positive charge density on C atoms increases which in turn makes them also active for facilitating HER. In addition, the encapsulated Co atoms also transfer electrons to the C atoms in CNTs, thus lowering the local work function and hence improving surface reactions. In another work, a novel synthesis strategy combining polymerization and pyrolysis was used to obtain Co/CoO NPs immobilized on Co-N-doped carbon (Fig. 2 e) and was reported as a trifunctional catalyst [68]. Similarly, other reports were made for HER with improved electrocatalytic performances and stability [66,67,69]. Co-phosphides: Co phosphides have been one of the most active compounds amongst the non-noble HER catalysts in acidic media. The HER mechanism in Co-phosphide is based on the “ensemble effect” [70]. The electronegativity of P (2.1) is higher than that of Co (1.9) and hence in Co-phosphide systems, the electron density is shifted towards P atom. Thus, Co gains a slight positive charge (Coδ+) and acts as the hydride acceptor, while P gains a slight negative charge (Pδ-) and acts as the proton acceptor to initiate HER [70–72]. Owing to this mechanism, high HER rates have been reported for Co-P catalysts [73–79]. Callejas et al. [80] observed that the cobalt-rich phosphides (as in Co2P) showed inferior HER rates as compared to Co-P catalyst. A more elaborate discussion on the changes in electrochemical activity and stability in metal-rich and phosphorus-rich Co-phosphides is provided in recent focused reviews [70,81,82]. Metal and non-metal doped Co-phosphides have shown better performance than undoped compounds, mainly due to the synergistic effects created by the inclusion of the dopant elements [83–85]. Metal ion dopants such as Mn, Al, Cu, Fe, Ce, Ni, etc. are found to improve the HER performance of base Co-P [86] by shifting ΔGH towards the thermoneutral value. In some cases, co-doping of Co phosphides with a metal and non-metal has also been tried. Co-doping with Zn & S [87], Cu & O [88], V & N [89] has been reported with improved HER rates. Co-chalcogenides: The family of metal chalcogenides are more widely known for the MoS2-type catalysts, prominently used in several industrial reactions [90]. For HER, the seminal reports on MoS2 suggest that only the S-edges in MoS2 are catalytically active and not the basal planes [91,92]. In earlier works, Co was used as an activity promoter to enhance the HER rates of MoS2-type catalysts [93,94]. However, eventually pyrite-phase Co-chalcogenides (CoS2, CoSe2) were discovered with much improved performances as compared to the conventional chalcogenides (MoS2, WS2) [95–102]. Zhang et al. [100] reported polymorphic CoSe2 with mixed orthorhombic and cubic phases, as a highly efficient HER catalyst with Tafel slope similar to that of Pt (30 mV/dec). The polymorphic catalysts showed better HER rates when compared to amorphous CoSex, cubic CoSe2 and CoSe. The performance of CoS2 and CoSe2 are also improved by incorporation of other transition-metals such as Ni [97,103] and Fe [104,105]. Cui et al. [106] compared the HER rates of first-row transition-metal dichalcogenides in acidic electrolyte. It was observed that Co-based catalysts (CoS2, FeCoS2 and CoSe2) showed the best HER rates compared to Ni and Fe-based chalcogenides ( Fig. 3). Moreover, recently CoSe2 @MoSe2 core-shell heterostructure was reported as a 3D HER catalyst in all pH conditions [107]. Co-sulphide was also investigated in the form of a high entropy alloy (Co-Zn-Cd-Cu-Mn-S) showing impressively low overpotential and high durability, suggesting it to be a good strategy for implementation [108]. In addition to the Co di-sulphides and di-selenides, another important configuration of Co-based HER catalyst are the Co9S8 phases. Co9S8 is reported extensively as a single catalyst [109,110] and also as a composite catalyst (Co9S8-MoS2 [111–114], Co9S8-CoSe2 [115], Co9S8-C [116] etc.) with highly improved performances. 3.1.2 Metalloid based Co-compounds Co-borides: Metal borides are the youngest class of HER electrocatalysts. The first report on the use of an amorphous metal boride catalyst for HER was made by our group in 2015 [46]. We presented Co-boride (Co-B) catalyst with excellent HER rates in neutral and near-neutral solutions. In this seminal report, the theory of “reverse electron transfer” was proposed for the first time to explain the higher HER rates in amorphous metal boride catalysts. As per this theory, the electron density in Co-B is shifted towards Co, making it more favorable for interaction with protons from the electrolyte and thus initiating HER. Despite Co having a lower electronegativity than B, the electron density shifts towards Co atoms and hence the term “reverse electron transfer” is used. This is now the most widely accepted theory explaining the higher HER rates in amorphous Co-based borides and metal borides, in general [117–125]. Following this report, a large number of Co-based borides were reported with improved performances and stability, in different pH solutions [118,120,121,123,126–132]. An elaborate account of the several catalysts belonging to the family of metal borides was published in a recent review by our group [133]. Some of the more common strategies reported in literature to improve the HER rates of Co-based borides are – doping with transition metals[118,121,130,132,134,135], doping with non-metals [47,136–138], nano-structuring [130,138–140] and making nano-composites [120,128,141]. Introduction of one or more transition-metal dopants in Co-B is one of the most effective strategies to improve the intrinsic HER activity due to the synergy induced between the metal atoms. Our group recently screened a series of transition-metals, namely Fe, Ni, Mo, Cu, W, Mn and Cr by including them in Co-B to form ternary Co-boride catalysts for HER in alkali and neutral solutions [142]. The trend in HER performance varied as Co-Mo-B > Co-W-B > Co-Ni-B > Co-Fe-B > Co-Cu-B > Co-Mn-B > Co-B in alkaline medium and as Co-Mo-B > Co-W-B > Co-Fe-B > Co-Ni-B > Co-Cu-B > Co-Mn-B > Co-B > Co-Cr-B in neutral medium. It was evidently suggested that Mo is the most ideal foreign element for inclusion in Co-B while the inclusion of Cr is detrimental to the HER activity. Apart from metals, several researchers tried to improve the HER rates by incorporating a non-metal (typically P) within Co-B [47,126,131,136–139,143,144,145]. As discussed in Section 3.1.1 ., Co-phosphides exhibit an electron transfer mechanism where Co loses electrons to P, a phenomenon completely opposite to the reverse electron transfer observed in amorphous Co-borides. In Co-phospho-boride (Co-P-B) systems, a combination of both these phenomena is observed, as there is an electron transfer from B to Co and then from Co to P. This unique interplay of electrons between B, Co and P is responsible for modulating the electron density at Co sites, making them more favorable for HER, as compared to Co-borides or Co-phosphides. This agrees with the Sebatier principle [60] that suggests an optimum interaction between the reactants and the catalyst substrate to achieve the best HER rates. Combining the advantages of bi-metallic Co-borides and Co-phospho-borides, bi-metallic Co-phospho-borides were also reported (Co-Fe-B-P [146], Co-Ni-P-B [131,139], Co-W-B-P [140] etc.) with improved HER performance and stability. Co-tellurides: Similar to Co-borides, Co-tellurides are also a young class of HER catalysts. However, Co-borides are primarily stable in neutral and alkali electrolytes, while Co-tellurides are reported to be stable in acidic regime as well. Recently, Cao et al. compared the HER rates of CoTe with NiTe nanoarrays and found that CoTe showed superior HER activity [147]. The authors proposed three theoretical assessment indicators (H2O adsorption energy, H2O dissociation barrier and H2/OH− desorption energy) to compare the HER activity of CoTe (101) and NiTe (101) with Pt (111). Using these indicators, the difference in HER rates for the three catalysts was vividly explained. Co-tellurides with different nanostructures were also reported with promising HER activities [148–152]. 3.1.3 Noble-metal based Co-compounds As discussed earlier, noble-metal based catalysts show excellent catalytic activities but are marred by their high-cost and limited availability. To minimize the use of these precious metals, researchers have tried making nanocomposites with inexpensive transition metals, such as Co. This strategy has not only resulted in lowering the cost of catalysts but also improving their catalytic performance. Pt-skin CoPtx was reported as efficient catalyst, with HER rates better than the conventional Pt/C [153]. Owing to the Pt-skin morphology, higher number of Pt atoms were exposed on the surface, to significantly improve Pt utilization. The inclusion of Co helps in altering the metal-metal bond length and also induce compressive strain due to the lattice mismatch, both the phenomena contributing towards higher HER activity. In a recent report by Uchida et al. [154], Pt-skin/Pt3Co showed an increment of 1.8 times in the HER rate compared to Pt alone ( Fig. 4 a). DFT studies on the Pt-skin/Pt3Co (110) surface suggested that Co affects the HER activity positively by weakening the Pt-H bonding and also altering the reaction mechanism. Similarly, other nanocomposites of Co and Pt also exhibited higher HER rates than Pt or Pt/C catalysts [155–158]. Ru, the cheapest Pt-group metal, was also used to make nanocomposites with Co [159–165]. RuCo nanoalloy embedded in N-doped graphene layers exhibited an extremely small overpotential value of 28 mV to achieve 10 mA/cm2 in 1 M KOH [161]. Based on the DFT calculations, the authors proposed that the RuCo alloy facilitates transfer of a greater number of electrons to the graphene layers, as compared to Co, which in turn reduces the Gibbs free energy for hydrogen adsorption (ΔGH*) and thus improves HER activity. A similar mechanism and electrochemical activity was reported by Liu et al. [160] for RuCo nanoalloy embedded within hollow carbon spheres. Li et al. [162] demonstrated that deposition of Ru nanoparticles on the surface of Co-carbonate hydroxides (Ru-CoCH) facilitates the HER. Here, CoCH is responsible for promoting the water dissociation process to produce Hads intermediates (Volmer step), while Ru nanoparticles assist in the conversion of these intermediates to H2 (Heyrovsky step) (Fig. 4 b). Similar to Pt and Ru, Co composites with other noble metals such as Pd and Ir were also reported as efficient HER catalysts [166–170]. 3.2 Oxygen evolution reaction (OER) OER is the kinetically sluggish counterpart of the HER that takes place on the anode. In overall water-splitting, OER is the energy intensive reaction and hence forms an important process. Unlike HER (a 2-electron process), OER is a 4-electron process and the intermediate reaction steps in different media are represented below: (3) In acidic solutions: 2 H2O(aq)→O2(g)+4 H++4e- The reaction steps can be elaborated as: M + H2O(aq)→MOH + H++e- MOH + OH-→MO+H2O(aq)+e- 2MO→2 M+O2(g) OR MO+H2O(aq)→MOOH+H++e- MOOH + H2O(aq)→M + O2(g)+H++e- (4) In alkali solutions: 4OH-→2 H2 + 2 H2O(aq) + 4e- The reaction steps in alkali medium can be elaborated as: M + OH-→MOH MOH + OH-→MO + H2O(aq) 2MO→2 M + O2(g) OR MO + OH-→MOOH + e- MOOH + OH-→M + O2(g) + H2O(aq) It must be noted that several groups have proposed different reaction steps for OER in acidic and alkali medium. In their review, Chen et al. presented a simplified illustration of the OER process ( Fig. 5a) depicting two routes to form O2 from a MO intermediate [11]. However, most of these models have similar reaction intermediates, such as MOH, MO and MOOH. The energy barrier for each of these steps is different and can be calculated computationally for specific catalysts. A recent review elaborates the various techniques and activity descriptors used for modelling the OER [10]. Similar to HER, the key parameters used to describe and compare the OER activity of different catalysts are overpotential, TOF, stability and recycling ability. The next sections list the main categories of Co-based OER catalysts that are prevalently used in literature. 3.2.1 Co-based oxides/hydroxides Layered double hydroxides: LDHs are an important class of OER catalysts with a 2D layered structure, more advantageous for catalysis than 0D or 1D architectures. The most general chemical formula for LDHs is [ M 1 − x II M x III ( OH ) 2 ] x + ( A n − ) x / n .mH2O [172]. Here, Co can occupy the M II position (as in CoFe LDH [171–175]) or the M III position (as in NiCo LDH [176–180]) to form stable LDHs. Fig. 5b shows a schematic of a CoFe LDH structure with carbonate ions intercalation [171]. CoFe LDHs are characterized by optimal electronic configuration in terms of eg level occupancy as desired for OER catalysis [181,182]. Defect-induced CoFe LDHs were found to exhibit higher OER activity than pristine catalysts [183–185]. The defects induced by exfoliation increases the number of unsaturated metal sites which in turn improves conductivity. The effect of oxygen vacancies on enhancing the conductivity and adsorption of water molecules was also reported for FexCoy-ONS catalyst [186]. Burke et al. found a ∼100 times enhancement in intrinsic OER activity of CoOOH catalyst after incorporation of Fe [187]. Here, an optimum ratio of Fe provided the active sites for OER while CoOOH provided the required conductivity and stability. Apart from Fe, Co-Mn [188–191] and Co-Zn LDHs [192–194]were also reported for OER. Co-based LDHs with different morphological variations were also developed to improve the OER rates. The conventional synthesis strategy for NiCo LDH is a tedious multi-step process. Jin et al. [180] presented a direct synthesis strategy to produce thin nanoplates of NiCo LDH with high OER activity which can be adopted for easy fabrication of LDHs. Multi-metal oxides/hydroxides: In Co-oxides/hydroxides, the Co atom usually acts as the catalytic center to facilitate OER. In Co-based multi-metal oxides, one, two or more metals are incorporated along with Co, where each metal plays a specific role. This is evident from the various reports on bi-metallic and tri-metallic Co-based oxide catalysts for OER, such as FeCoO [195], CoNiFe/MnO [196], NiCo2−xFexO4 [197], Co–Fe–V-O [198], FexCo1−xCeOy [199], etc. The most prominent effect of the inclusion of different metals is the modification of the electronic structure of the catalyst. As per Kang et al. [24], in multi-metal oxides, the inclusion of foreign metals alters the electronic structure due to two prominent effects – the strain effect and the ligand effect. This is valid for Co-based multi-metal oxides as well. A typical class of bi-metallic oxides are represented by AB2O4, where A and B are transition-metals, including several Co-based catalysts that are found to facilitate OER. For instance, a hierarchical architecture of CoNi/CoFe2O4 on Ni foam was reported to achieve current densities approaching 1 A/cm2 in an alkaline electrolyte [200]. Likewise, Co2TiO4 nanocrystals [201] and ZnCo2O4 nanochains [202] show much improved OER rates in an acidic electrolyte, when compared to Co3O4. Zheng et al. [203] studied different combinations of multi-metal Co hydroxides, with and without Li ions. For a complex system such as Li-Ni-Mn-Co-OH, they observed that the inclusion of Li causes the Co ions to stay in higher valence states (4+), which is advantageous for OER. Sargent et al. [204] performed systematic investigations to develop W-incorporated Fe-Co-hydroxides with exceptional OER activity (191 mV for 10 mA/cm2) in 1 M KOH. Based on DFT + U calculations, the authors found that the OH adsorption energy was too strong on FeOOH surface while it was too weak on the CoOOH and WO3 surfaces. In Fe-and W-doped CoOOH ternary system, a near-optimal OH* energetics was observed for OER. When a W dopant was substituted at the Co4+ site, an OER rate enhancement was observed due to two effects – transfer of protons from W sites to the Co sites and inducement of compressive strain on the Co sites due to larger W atoms. Likewise, V-incorporated CoFe oxides were recently designed and developed with excellent OER performance and stability [198]. Perovskites: Perovskites are one of the most popular class of oxides that have recently gained much attention for OER as well. The general formula for a perovskite is ABO3, where the A site is usually occupied by a rare-earth or alkali earth metals (La, Sr, etc.) while the B site is occupied by a transition-metal (Co, Fe, etc.) [205,206]. However, other forms of perovskites such as double perovskites (A2BB’O6) and layered perovskites (An+1BnO3n+1) are also reported [207,208]. In Co-based perovskites, Co-atom occupies the B-site, as in compounds such as LaCoO3 or SrCoO3. One of the more common strategies to improve the OER rates of Co-based perovskites is through substitution of Co by other transition-metals. Fe substituted LaCoO3 is found to possess better OER kinetics than pristine LaCoO3, attributed to the increased spin state of Co3+ [209]. Schmidt et al. [210] investigated the role of Fe in improving the OER activity and stability of two Co-based perovskites, namely Ba0.5Sr0.5Co0.8Fe0.2O3–δ (BSCF) and La0.2Sr0.8Co0.8Fe0.2O3−δ (LSCF). The authors found that the inclusion of Fe allows Co to attain charge stability in a lower oxidation state and prevents the formation of side oxide phases, which in turn provides favorable environment for the growth of the active Co oxy(hydroxide) layer. A composite of BSCF with carbon was also found to portray better OER rates as carbon induces reduction of Co to maintain it in lower oxidation states [205]. Grimaud et al. [211] proposed a new family of Co-based double perovskites (Ln0.5Ba0.5)CoO3-δ (with Ln = Pr, Sm, Gd and Ho) as highly active catalysts for OER, with (Pr0.5Ba0.5)CoO3-δ being the most active member, thus establishing the relevance of Co-based perovskites for use in OER. Spinels: Co-based spinel oxides are some of the oldest reported catalysts for OER. Cobaltite (Co3O4) is the fundamental spinel oxide that has been explored extensively for OER, especially in alkaline medium owing to its exceptional stability [212–220]. However, Co ions can be partially replaced by other metallic cations to form several derivatives of Co-based spinel oxides (NiCo2O4, CoFe2O4, etc.). The OER activity of Co3O4 depends on the ratio of Co2+/Co3+ and it has been observed that a higher number of Co2+ results in better performance. Thus, many reports have emphasized on introducing oxygen vacancies in Co3O4 in a bid to increase the ratio of Co2+/Co3+ and thus facilitate OER kinetics [221,222]. Another common strategy to enhance the performance of Co3O4 catalyst is to develop different nanostructures. Our group developed dimension-confined nanostructures of Co3O4 in the form of nanoparticles (0D), nanowires (1D), nanosheets (2D) and nanocrystals (3D) [213]. We not only established the OER rates of each of these nanostructures but also studied the effect of various parameters on the OER rate, such as the physical and electroactive surface area, phase/structure and orientation of the crystallographic planes of Co3O4. Similarly, there have been several reports on Co3O4 catalyst in the form of nanoflakes [223–226], nanocubes [227–232], hollow microtube arrays [233,234], urchin-like structures [216,235,236], etc. In addition to conventional water-splitting, recently our group reported a unique Co3O4-based catalyst for OER in alkali simulated seawater [237]. Through chemical boronation, the surface of Fe-doped Co3O4 catalyst was enriched with boron to produce a core-shell structure ( Fig. 6 a). The boron-rich shell and the presence of Fe leads to the formation of a large number of active CoOOH species, imparts a lower charge-transfer resistance and improves the intrinsic activity to significantly enhance the OER activity as compared to Co3O4 in pure and saline water. 3.2.2 Co-based non-oxides Over the years, several non-oxide catalysts were discovered with promising OER activities, even surpassing the performance of conventional oxides. Some of these prominent categories of Co-based non-oxide catalysts are Co-phosphides [238–243], Co-borides [127,138,244–250], Co- chalcogenides [251–258], etc. As discussed in Section 3.1 , these catalysts are also active for HER and hence they are called bifunctional catalysts, capable of efficiently catalyzing both the half-reactions of water electrolysis. However, it must be noted that these non-oxide catalysts are not the active species and are just the ‘pre-catalysts’ for OER. Mullins et al. [54] presented a new perspective to look at such materials and proposed that during OER these non-oxide catalysts are partially or completely oxidized to form OER active (oxy)hydroxide species (Fig. 6b). This oxidation of the pre-catalyst often results in higher surface area, which is advantageous for catalysis. Also, in most cases, only partial oxidation of the pre-catalyst takes place while the underlying bulk remains unoxidized and possesses higher conductivity for electron transfer, thus facilitating OER kinetics. For Co-borides, our group presented direct experimental evidence of the formation of Co oxy-hydroxides on the surface of Co-B thin film during alkali water oxidation [259]. XPS data were obtained from different depths of the catalyst film post OER to estimate a thickness of around 15 nm for the oxy-hydroxide film. Despite Co oxy-hydroxide being the OER active species, the role of the pre-catalyst Co-B was manifested with experimental evidence. It was shown that boron donates electrons to Co, thus maintaining Co atoms in a reduced state and prevents the formation of stable Co oxides. This reduced Co surface shows a lower energy barrier towards the formation of Co oxy-hydroxide and thus the Co-B pre-catalyst also plays a definitive role in enhancing the OER activity. In Co-phosphides, it was observed that Co-rich catalyst (Co2P) showed better OER rates than the mono-metallic phosphide (Co-P) [260]. This enhancement was attributed to the higher metallic character of Co2P which eventually helps in electron conduction. The precise role of phosphorous in enhancing the OER rates is not clear, however it is reported that during OER, the phosphide is converted into phosphate that acts as a labile ligand and facilitates OER [261]. Recently, our group reported a new benchmark OER mass activity (666 A/g at η = 300 mV) and a sub-200 mV overpotential (η10 ∼ 195 mV) using a bi-metallic phospho-boride catalyst (Co-Mo-PB) ( Fig. 7a) [248]. The superior OER performance of the catalyst was attributed to the synergistic effect created due to the inclusion of Mo and P atoms in Co-B. He et al. [262] summarized the OER performances of some Co-based chalcogenides (Fig. 7b) and found that CeO2/CoSe2 composite showed the lowest overpotential amongst the chosen catalysts. 3.2.3 OER/ORR bifunctional catalysts Similar to the role of OER in water electrolyzers, ORR plays a key role in other electrochemical devices such as fuel cells and metal-air batteries [263]. Especially in metal-air batteries, OER and ORR are complementing reactions taking place on the surface of the catalysts during charging and discharging cycles, respectively [264]. Thus, OER/ORR bifunctional catalysts have emerged as highly desired materials for battery applications. ORR is a cathodic reaction that follows either a two-electron pathway to produce hydrogen peroxide or a four-electron pathway to reduce oxygen [265,266]. Apparently, the latter is usually desired where oxygen is taken from the air instead of contributing to the battery weight. Electrocatalysts and their structures can cause differences in the ORR pathways and mechanisms. Additionally, ORR exhibits structure-sensitive behavior even with identical catalysts. Cobalt-based materials can be synthesized in different structures, combined with other transition/precious metals, or with ligands like sulfur and nitrogen that makes them one of the most promising OER/ORR bifunctional electrocatalysts. Nanostructured Co3O4 shows promising bifunctional OER/ORR properties due to the presence of highly active sites and durability in alkaline medium. Ahmed et al. synthesized nano cactus-like structure of Co3O4 material embedded on CNTs that showed excellent bifunctional activity and stability due to the high density of active sites and excellent charge transport capability [267]. Tao et al. have also synthesized Co3O4 nanorods/GNS (graphene nanosheets) nanocomposites with outstanding electrochemical properties owing to their distinctive structure. The one-dimensional structure of Co3O4 prevents its aggregation and lowers the degree of stacking in GNS, thus providing an exceptional pathway for ion diffusion and electronic conduction [268]. Due to their versatile physical and chemical characteristics, Co-based metal organic frameworks (MOFs) and their derivatives have also been exploited as effective precursors. Numerous carbon-based nanomaterials (as supports) have been created by making use of the special characteristics of MOF structure, including their enormous surface area, customizable porosity, and ease of functionalization with additional heteroatoms or metals or metal oxides. A Co-CoxO/NC electrocatalyst was derived from cobalt-based MOF and combined with an appropriate ratio of carbon black to achieve extremely high OER/ORR bifunctional activity, surpassing that of IrO2 (for OER) and Pt/C (for ORR) [269]. A similar high bifunctional performance was also reported for Co@Co3O4/FeNS-RGO composite [270], which establishes the significance of Co-based materials for OER/ORR catalysis. 3.3 Hydrolysis of chemical hydrides Though water electrolysis is an ideal method for producing renewable H2, its applications are limited to off-site H2 production. In applications where on-site H2 generation is required with a high production rate, such as for vehicular applications, dissociation of H2-containing compounds such as chemical hydrides is a better alternative. Chemical hydrides have high H2 storage capacity in terms of volumetric and gravimetric efficiencies and are promising candidates to obtain pure H2 at a very high rate, suitable for on-board applications [12,14]. In presence of appropriate catalysts, the chemical hydrides can be dissociated efficiently to obtain pure H2 gas. Various chemical hydrides such as sodium borohydride, ammonia borane, lithium borohydride, potassium borohydride, magnesium hydride and sodium hydride have been studied extensively to produce pure H2 for use in fuel cells at room temperature. Amongst these, ammonia borane (NH3BH3) and sodium borohydride (NaBH4) have gained more attention owing to their high gravimetric and volumetric hydrogen storage capacity and also because they are stable, non-flammable and non-toxic [12,14,271]. The gravimetric hydrogen densities in NH3BH3 and NaBH4 are 19.5 wt% and 10.8 wt%, respectively [271]. The chemical reactions illustrating the hydrolysis of NH3BH3 (Eq. 5) and NaBH4 (Eq. 6) are represented below: (5) NH3BH3 + 3 H2O→NH3 + B(OH)3 + 3 H2 (6) NaBH4 + 2 H2O→NaBO2 + 4 H2 To effectively enhance the hydrolysis reaction rate, several inorganic and organic catalysts have been tested. Amongst these, noble metal catalysts like Pt, Pd and Ru have displayed a high hydrogen generation rate that is required for practical purposes [272–276]. However, due to the high cost and scarcity of these catalysts, they seem to be not viable for industrial applications. Given the scenario, it is important to have a catalyst that is low in cost and is available in plenty with sustained activity and stability like the noble metals. Various transition metals in oxides form or attached to various metalloids have been tested. Among the transition metals, cobalt-based catalysts have shown promising results and their lower cost makes them interesting choices to replace the noble metal catalysts. In some cases, Co was combined with noble metals (such as Pt [277]) to further improve their catalytic rates. To estimate the improvement in performance of the catalyst, the hydrogen gas produced due to the dissociation process is measured as a function of time and the hydrogen generation rate (in mlH2/min/gcat) is calculated [12]. In some cases, the reaction is performed at increasing temperatures and activation energies are calculated using the Arrhenius equation [12]. In the following sections, we discuss Co as a catalyst in different forms that can be efficiently used for the hydrolysis of chemical hydrides. 3.3.1 Cobalt nanoparticles The hydrolysis reaction is an aqueous reaction where the catalyst is usually dispersed in the solution in the form of powders. Hence, despite being catalytically active, the Co nanoparticles tend to lose their activity over long-term use, owing to agglomeration. To overcome this issue, most of the recent reports are focused on supporting Co nanoparticles on high surface area supports. Co supported on 3D graphene oxide could achieve a high hydrogen generation rate of 4394 mlH2min−1g−1 cobalt at 298 K [278]. Seven et al. [279] synthesized Co and Ni incorporated poly(acrylamide) cryogel network and used them for hydrolysis of NaBH4 in aqueous alkali solution ( Fig. 8). They observed that the Co-incorporated cryogels showed better activity than the Ni-incorporated cryogels, establishing the supremacy of Co ion catalysts. Zhang et al. [280] synthesized ultrafine Co nanoparticles (∼7 nm) supported on carbon nanospheres that yield a H2 generation rate of 7447 mlH2min−1gM −1 at 303 K for hydrolysis of NaBH4. Co was incorporated on the surface of graphitic carbon nitride for photo-assisted hydrolysis of aqueous ammonia borane [281]. Likewise, other reports were made on using Co nanoparticles by supporting them on similar conducting supports [280,282]. 3.3.2 Cobalt oxide nanoparticles Similar to metallic Co catalysts, Co oxide catalysts have also been predominantly used for the dissociation of chemical hydrides. To overcome the conventional issue of catalyst agglomeration, our group explored the use of Co oxide thin film catalysts, fabricated using pulsed laser deposition for hydrolysis of NaBH4 [33]. When fabricated in the form of thin films, the Co oxide nanoparticles attain an extremely small size distribution (∼3–10 nm) and these nanoparticles are immobilized on the surface of the thin films. Thus, the nanoparticles remain dispersed on the substrate throughout the reaction, solving the issue of catalyst agglomeration. Such thin film catalysts are also preferred over powder catalysts as they provide a convenient way to recover the catalyst after use and also act as an ON/OFF switch for on-demand H2 generation. The hydrogen generation rate obtained using the Co oxide thin film catalyst was 5010 mlH2 min−1gcat −1, which was much higher than that of commercial Co3O4 powder (860 mlH2 min−1gcat −1) [283], Co3O4 macrocubes (1498 mlH2 min−1gcat −1) [284], Co3O4 synthesized by solution combustion method (2530 mlH2 min−1gcat −1) [285] and Co3O4-B powder catalyst (1248 mlH2 min−1gcat −1) [286]. Recently, Zhang et al. [287] synthesized Co3O4 powders from varied Co salts, such as CoSO4, CoCl2, Co(OAc)2, and Co(NO3)2. They observed that only the catalyst obtained from sulfur-containing cobalt salt was active for hydrolysis of aqueous NaBH4. Hydrogen generation rate as high as 10366 ml.min−1g−1 was observed for CoO nanorods in the shape of thin nanonails where the high catalytic rate is attributed to the unique morphology [288]. 3.3.3 Cobalt boride nanoparticles The chemical hydrides, especially NaBH4 and NH3BH3 are both reducing agents, the former one being much stronger than the latter. Hence, in aqueous solutions, these hydrides tend to reduce the Co ions conveniently, forming amorphous boride phases. In the early 1950′s Schlesinger et al. [289] for the first time showed that a mixture of NaBH4 pellets with cobalt chloride resulted in a black precipitate of Co-B. The powder obtained through such reactions is usually amorphous in nature, attributed to the rapid reduction process, and is catalytically superior to metallic Co or Co oxide catalysts. However, owing to excessive agglomeration, the catalytic performance of Co-B is usually suppressed, making it unsuitable for practical applications. One way to avoid agglomeration is to introduce an atomic barrier in the form of transition metals [290]. These promoter metals, even at small atomic concentrations, significantly enhance the surface area by avoiding any kind of agglomeration in the Co-B catalyst. Apart from enhancing the surface area, the doped transition metals also act as Lewis acid sites to enhance the adsorption of the reactants. In our previous work, we investigated the role of the dopant transition metals: Ni, Fe, Cu, Cr, Mo, and W on the catalytic efficiency of the Co–B powder for H2 generation by hydrolysis of sodium borohydride and ammonia borane [290,291]. Each dopant behaved in a different way while influencing the catalytic activity. The metal/(Co + metal) molar ratio was varied in order to study the effect of each metal dopant concentration on the catalytic efficiency. We observed that the best promoting effects were obtained with specific molar concentration (4% Cr in case of NaBH4 and 3% Mo in case of NH3BH3) of the transition metals. The promoting effects of the dopants are related to: (a) large active surface area of the catalysts in case of Co–Fe–B, Co–Cu–B, Co– Cr–B, Co–Mo–B, Co–W–B, (b) the ability to act as Lewis acid sites for better adsorption of OH groups (Co–Cr–B, Co–Mo–B, Co–W–B), (c) electronic interaction with Co active metal (Co–Ni–B, Co–Fe–B), i.e., transfer of electrons from Fe and Ni to Co and (d) amorphous nature of the alloy catalyst. There are other ways to enhance the activity of Co-B. Recently, Wang et al. [292] synthesized Co-Cu-B in form of hollow spherical nanoparticles for hydrolysis of alkaline NaBH4. The enhanced catalytic activity is due to the unique structure and the synergistic effect of Co, Cu and B atoms. By introducing multi-metals (Fe and Ru) and using a polymer support, Co-Fe-Ru-B catalyst powder could achieve an extremely high H2 generation rate of 36978 mlH2min−1gcat −1 [293]. To take advantage of the thin film coatings, our group developed a Co-B-O catalyst using pulsed laser deposition (PLD) with improved activity and stability for hydrolysis of NaBH4 solutions [294]. 3.4 CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) One of the primary contributions responsible for global warming is the rising carbon concentration in the atmosphere, caused by enormous CO2 emissions. Having realized this issue, several measures (such as CO2 sequestration [295,296]) have been tried with little success. Despite being an atmospheric nuisance, CO2 is a high value industrial product that can be converted to usable fuel products through CO2RR [297], thus contributing towards achieving a carbon-neutral economy. Similar to water-splitting, CO2RR can be realized using three methods – electrocatalytic, photocatalytic and photo-electrocatalytic [17]. Hence, most of the metrics used to evaluate the performance of a catalyst for water-splitting reactions are also valid for CO2RR. The key additional parameter that needs special attention in CO2RR is the selectivity of products formed. Ideally, it is desired that a chosen catalyst remains selective for a single product that translates into a Faradaic efficiency of 100% [298]. However, the complexity of the reaction makes it a difficult task and controlling the selectivity of the reaction product remains one of the key challenges in CO2RR. Table 1 lists the various possible products that can be formed during the reduction of CO2, at specific reduction potentials [299]. Another critical challenge faced during CO2RR is the kinetic competition with HER at cathodic potentials in aqueous solutions, which may dominate and reduce the Faradaic efficiency of the desired product. A schematic of the two possible routes for CO2RR and the possible competition with HER in aqueous solutions is illustrated in Fig. 9 [17]. When it comes to Co-based catalysts, they are often considered to preferentially convert CO2 into CO and HCOOH [16]. However, recently there have been reports where obtaining other carbon products have also been made possible with different Co-based catalysts. Here, it must be noted that the role of Co-based catalysts will be limited to being a redox catalyst (not photo-absorbers), be it for electrocatalysis or for photo(electro)catalysis. Some of the most promising and heavily researched classes of Co-based catalysts are discussed in the following sections. 3.4.1 Cobalt phthalocyanine (CoPc) CoPcs are one of the most widely studied CO2RR molecular redox catalysts and are being explored for over half a century now [300–306]. In recent times, Wang et al. reported CoPc/CNT hybrid nanostructures with Faradaic efficiencies of > 95% for CO [300] and > 40% for electrocatalytic methanol production [307]. Zhang et al. [308] studied a series of metal phthalocyanines (MePcs), namely that of Mn, Fe, Co, Ni and Cu for electrocatalytic conversion of CO2 into CO. DFT calculations showed that amongst the chosen MePcs, CoPc was the most ideal catalyst, depicting a moderate *CO bonding energy leading to an optimum activity for CO formation. This was well reflected in the experimental data [ Fig. 10a-d] where CoPc could achieve a Faradaic efficiency of ∼99% for CO formation. Moreover, the Faradaic efficiency of CoPc was maintained > 90% for over 60 h of operation. The effect of two different carbon supports, namely Vulcan XC-72 and carbon nanotubes (CNTs) on the electrocatalytic activity of CoPc was evaluated for CO formation [309]. Being treated as a heterogeneous molecular catalyst, CoPc/CNT showed better performance and stability than CoPc-XC-72, which was attributed to better dispersion and a strong interaction between CoPc and CNT (π- π interaction). Ren et al. [310] demonstrated the use of CoPc in a zero-gap membrane assembly to electrochemically convert CO2 to CO and achieved selectivity > 95% at 150 mA/cm2, illustrating the possibility of integrating CoPc into commercial systems. CoPc was recently also explored in conjunction with semiconductors for photocatalytic/photo-electrocatalytic CO2RR. The inclusion of fluorine in CoPc (CoFPc) makes the catalyst hydrophobic and thus improves its adsorption on the support surfaces [303,311]. Such a CoFPc catalyst coated on carbon cloth was used as the cathode in a 2-electrode PEC cell for CO2RR [311]. 3.4.2 Single atom Co catalysts The last decade saw the emergence of a new concept in catalysis which is now commonly referred to as ‘single atom catalysis’ [312–314]. Single atom catalysts (SACs) refer to such materials where single and isolated metal atoms are anchored on a specific support and act as the heterogeneous catalytic sites. Co SACs have been used extensively in different areas of catalysis, including CO2RR [315–320]. Zhang et al. [318] developed a new composite, MOF-525-Co, by incorporating unsaturated Co sites in MOF-525 matrix for photocatalytic CO2 reduction. This composite ensured that the active Co sites do not aggregate and remained exposed to facilitate CO2RR, while MOF-525 served as the photo-absorber. First principles simulations confirmed that the photogenerated electrons were effectively transferred from MOF structure to Co active sites, thus facilitating charge separation and also improving the CO2 adsorption capability of the catalyst. In another work, Co was atomically dispersed on nitrogen-doped porous carbon to yield Co-N4, Co-N3 and Co-N2 catalysts for electrochemical reduction of CO2 [319]. The authors investigated the effect of varying Co co-ordination number and found that the activity and selectivity towards CO formation increases as the Co-N coordination number decreases from 4 to 2. Interestingly, in their other work, the same group reported Co-N5 coordination state to be the most effective in reducing CO2 to CO with > 90% FE [316]. Yang et al. [315] constructed a 3D free-standing electrode by incorporating Co single atoms in carbon nanofibers. This 3D electrode was tested in an electrochemical flow-cell configuration and could achieve a FE ∼92% for CO formation, generating a partial current density of 211 mA/cm2 at − 0.9 VRHE, suggesting its upscaling feasibility. 3.4.3 Cobalt, cobalt oxides and cobalt composites An insightful study by Yanagimachi et al. [321] showed that CO2 dissociatively adsorbs on the surface of cobalt nanocluster ions (Con -) but not on the Co atomic anion. They determined that a cluster size ≥ 7 is required for the interaction of CO2 with Con -. Co nanoclusters were also embedded into a MOF to obtain a porous co-catalyst (Co6-MOF), which was coupled with a ruthenium-based photo-sensitizer for photocatalytic CO2RR [322]. As per the proposed mechanism, the photogenerated electrons from the sensitizer were transferred to Co6-MOF to activate the adsorbed CO2 molecules and convert them into CO. In addition to metallic cobalt, cobalt oxides are also reported as efficient catalysts for CO2RR. Co oxide, in the form of ultrathin Co3O4 layers, was developed with thicknesses of 1.72 nm and 3.51 nm [323] and it was found that the ultrathin layers offer large number of active sites, thus enabling adsorption of higher amounts of CO2. DFT studies indicated higher dispersed charge density that increases the electronic conductivity and improves electrochemical CO2RR activity. A core-shell structure consisting of Co3O4 octahedrons coated with Co3S4 surface was used for electrochemical CO2RR as well as ORR ( Fig. 11) [324]. The heterojunction between the p-type Co3O4 core and the n-type Co3S4 shell imparts a specific electronic structure that facilitates both types of catalytic processes. Similarly, cobalt-iron oxide (Co2FeO4) nanosheets were reported as a bifunctional electrocatalyst for electrochemical Co2RR and OER [325]. The catalyst was used as cathode and anode in a photocatalyst system driven by a GaInP2/GaAs/Ge triple-junction solar cell. For a test period of 30 h, average Faradaic efficiency of 92.3% was observed for CO formation with a current density of 13.1 mA/cm2, which eventually results in a solar to fuel conversion efficiency (STFCO) of 15.5%. 4 Co-based catalysts in environmental applications Organic pollutants in water, air and soil are major concerns to the environment, if present in large quantities. Many conventional methods are deemed ineffective in the removal of these recalcitrant organics especially from aqueous media where their soluble nature makes them even more challenging to extract. In the last decade, AOPs involving reactive oxygen species (ROS) have emerged as a very attractive and viable option to degrade these organic matters to less toxic compounds or completely mineralize them into unharmful by-products (CO2 and water) [326]. To initiate both these processes, strong oxidizing species such as sulfate radicals ( SO 4 ⦁ − ) and hydroxyl radicals ( HO ⦁ ) generated in-situ are required for oxidation of organic pollutants. For certain degradation reactions, even oxygen-based species ( O 2 ⦁ − and O 3 ⦁ − ) and direct photolysis using UV-light are used efficiently. For all types of AOPs, catalyst plays a key role in the activation of oxidant. Among transition metals, cobalt was found to be the most effective specifically for SO 4 ⦁ − generation mainly attributed to the highest standard reduction potential of Co3+/Co2+ (E0 = 1.92 V) in transition metals [27,327,328]. Along with this, the magnetic nature makes cobalt-based catalysts highly favorable for separation from the aqueous medium. The following sections are devoted towards highlighting the role of Co-based compound catalysts in generating two main ROS ( SO 4 ⦁ − and HO ⦁ ) through activation of oxidants. 4.1 Sulfate radicals based AOPs AOPs through SO 4 ⦁ − is a very attractive alternative for remediation of wastewater from organic contaminants like dyes, pharmaceutical by-products, bio-chemical affluents, insecticides, herbicides, phenolic continents, plasticizers and other endocrine disruptors. Interest towards SO 4 ⦁ − based oxidation arises owing to the series of merits over HO ⦁ radicals, mainly high oxidation potential, selectivity, activity, operable in wide pH and higher lifetime [329–331]. Although SO 4 ⦁ − can be generated by activation of peroxymonosulfate (PMS, HSO5 -) through direct routes, but if produced via catalyst, it provides the advantage of eliminating the requirement of external input energy and makes the process viable for long term operation. In the past, activation of PMS was carried out using ions of various transition metals (Ni2+, Fe2+, Ce3 +, Cu2+, Co2+, and Mn2+), but Co2+ was found to be the most efficient activator for PMS amongst all [332]. Even if the first report on activation of PMS was reported way back in 1958 [333], within the last decade, substantial investigations were carried out by implementing various strategies to enhance the kinetics of the activation process and study the reaction mechanism [27,327,334]. The following equations (Eqs. 7 – 10) illustrate the Co2+ mediated activation process of PMS. (7) Co 2 + + H 2 O → CoO H + + H + (8) CoOH + + HS O 5 − → Co O + + SO 4 ⦁ − + H 2 O (9) CoO + + 2 H + → C o 3 + + H 2 O (10) Co 3 + + HS O 5 − → C o 2 + + SO 4 ⦁ − + H + Here, the formation of CoOH+ by reacting with H2O triggers the formation of SO 4 ⦁ − radicals but regeneration of Co2+ from Co3+ is the rate-limiting step to maintain the reactions. Hence, usually high concentration of Co2+ is utilized to attain a high degradation rate which generally adds to secondary pollutants and at the same time excess amount of Co2+ reduces the utilization rate of PMS by reaction with SO 4 ⦁ − [333]. In order to avoid a high concentration of Co2+, chemical reagents [335,336] and inorganic compounds in the form of activated carbon [337] are used to increase the efficiency of Co3+ to Co2+ conversion. Although the efficiency to activate PMS through homogeneous Co2+ is considerably high but the release of Co2+ in the water system can lead to the potential threat to the living beings and also increases operation cost owing to the constant requirement of Co2+ ions to sustain the process. On the other hand, heterogeneous catalyst just provides the surface for activation of PMS and converts Co3+ ions back to Co2+ without any loss of cobalt. Thus, majority of the research work is now focused on realizing heterogeneous cobalt-based catalysts such as cobalt oxide, supported cobalt catalysts and mixed cobalt oxides. 4.1.1 Cobalt oxides Among different phases of cobalt oxides, CoO offers the highest catalytic activity for the generation of SO 4 ⦁ − which is attributed to the homogeneous nature of the reaction where leaching of Co2+ ions take place [338]. While Co3O4 phase composed of Co3+ and Co2+ offers moderate activity but it presents high stability on the bases of the efficient redox cycle of Co2+/Co3+. Investigation of various characteristics of Co3O4 showed that not only the phase but also the surface features such as facets, surface area and morphology also play prime roles in deciding the catalytic activity. Wang et al. [39] successfully realized nano-cube, nanorod, and nano-octahedron of Co3O4 with (100), (110), and (111) facets ( Fig. 12a-l) respectively. Co3O4 with (110) plane displayed the lowest adsorption energy calculated by DFT, and this finding was corelated well with the highest catalytic degradation rate of phenols through sulfate radicals (Fig. 12m-n). By controlling the reaction conditions and chemical reagents, Li and co-workers [339] fabricated 4 different nano-morphologies - needle-like, plates-like, floral-like, and cube-like Co3O4 with different specific surface areas ( Fig. 13a-h). Co3O4 with a floral-like structure exhibited a surface area of 121.1 m2/g and presented the highest catalytic performance by activation of PMS owing to the availability of a large number of Co2+ (Fig. 13i-l). 4.1.2 Supported cobalt catalysts Supported cobalt-compounds not only provide the advantage of the atomic-level dispersion of cobalt but also suppresses the loss of cobalt ions. Both these features enhance the activity and stability by exposing a large number of active sites that are firmly anchored on the support materials via interaction between metal and support [340]. Among various oxide supports, Co3O4 supported on TiO2 [341] and MgO [342] displayed higher activation of PMS as a result of basic characteristics of these oxide supports, favouring the dispersion of acidic cobalt ions and expediting the formation of the active CoOH+ species on the support surface [343]. In order to improve the basicity of the SBA-15 mesoporous silica, Hu et al. [344] loaded Mg onto the support to aid higher order of dispersion of Co3O4 on the support and accelerate the CoOH+ formation. Another key advantage of decorating Co3O4 on the photocatalysts like TiO2 and ZnO is that both these materials can absorb UV light and produce e-/h+ pairs [345,346]. These photo-generated electrons facilitate the reduction of Co3+ to Co2+ and also participate in the activation of PMS, while h+ having oxidation property can directly as well as via HO ⦁ formation, oxidizes the organic pollutant. Molecular sieve supports, for instance zeolites, have also been used in the past where cobalt ions were incorporated at the atomic scale by the ion-exchange technique. Despite the high catalytic activity shown by this zeolite-supported cobalt, the stability was not achieved as a result of cobalt leaching out. MOFs with large surface areas, provided by the porous network and high chemical and thermal stability, presents a conducive environment to support Co3O4 with a high amount of dispersion. ZIF67, a cobalt-based MOF, was found to be very effective to activate PMS for the degradation of Rhodamine B (RhB) dye, as reported by Lin et al. [347]. Yolk-shell Co3O4/MOF nanocomposite synthesized by solvothermal method, incorporates a gap between core and shell which act as the nanoreactor to first allow 4-chlorophenol to enter and then degrade them through activation of PMS [348]. Among all the supports used, carbon-based supports present several merits. In addition to the large surface area, better dispersion and stability, the carbon support also participates in activating PMS to generate SO 4 ⦁ − radicals [349–352]. The conductive nature of carbon also facilitates the transfer of electrons between cobalt species and PMS. Along with this, carbon supports such as reduced-graphene-oxide (rGO), due to the variety of functional groups on their surface, promotes the adsorption of reactive species on the surface of catalyst for immediate interaction with SO 4 ⦁ − radicals formed by cobalt on a carbon support [353,354]. Graphitic carbon nitride (gC3N4) has the capability to organize cobalt as a single atom in the nitrogen pots of 2D heptazine structure [355]. This arrangement also allows the formation of new reactive species such as Co-N, Co-N-C, and Co-C to provide an additional feature to enhance the catalytic performance. 4.1.3 Mixed metal cobalt oxides Mixed metal oxides present multifunctional features based on the synergic effect produced between the different metals. For example, electronic interaction between cobalt and foreign metal improves the redox cycle of Co3+/Co2+ and leads to higher activation efficiency of PMS. Cobalt-based spinels, perovskites and LDHs are the most common forms of catalyst studied for activation of PMS. Perovskites with two configurations of ACoO3 and ACoMO3 (A = La, Sr, Ce or Ba and M = Fe, Ti, Mn or Mo) are largely studied for degradation of organic pollutants of water by generating SO 4 ⦁ − radicals [356,357]. The atomic radius of A influences the catalytic activity of ACoO3 as reported by Hammouda et al. [358]. The same group along with Duan et al. [359] also provided evidence that the presence of oxygen vacancies and Co-O-M bonds in perovskites assists in the reduction of Co3+ to Co2+ and also aid in electron transfer from cobalt to PMS during activation. The interaction between Co and M in spinel structure of Co-based catalysts (CoFe2O4, NiCo2O4, and CuCo2O4) generated a synergic effect to enhance SO 4 ⦁ − generation by inhibiting leaching of Co2+ ions and increase the ratio of Co2+/Co3+ by reduction of Co3+ [360–362]. Cu metal in CuCo2O4 also participates in the activation of PMS to increase the degradation performance for organic matter [363]. Cobalt ferrite (CoFe2O4) has the advantage of being easily separable from the reaction due to its magnetic nature. In addition, the electronic interaction between Fe2+ and Co3+ promotes the regeneration of Co2+ ions. Mixed metal LDH with layered structure yields large number of active sites on the edge of the layer to enhance the activation of PMS for removal of organic effluents [364,365]. The spacing between the layers also allows the reactant to move freely during the catalytic reactions. 4.2 Hydroxyl radicals based AOPs AOPs involving HO ⦁ are most commonly used for effective removal of recalcitrant organic compounds. Factors like high reaction rate, strong standard potential (+2.8 V vs NHE), and the non-selective nature of the reaction, makes HO ⦁ based AOPs very efficient for wastewater remediation from organic compounds. Traditionally, HO ⦁ radicals were produced by several processes such as UV photolysis (direct or via catalyst), ozonation, electro-chemical and ultrasound irradiation, non-thermal plasma and γ-rays & electron beam irradiation [366]. Amongst all these, UV photolysis involving catalysts is found to be very attractive owing to the requirement of the limited amounts of reactive reagents and energy consumption to produce a high reaction rate. In this route, OH- radicals are produced by either using Fe-based catalyst in Fenton type reaction or using metal oxides (TiO2, ZnO and WO3) via direct photocatalysis [366]. Former requires H2O2 as oxidizing reagents to produce HO ⦁ while photocatalysis reaction proceeds by direct production of HO ⦁ radicals through oxidation of water under UV light irradiation. In classical Fenton reaction, a homogeneous mixture of Fe2+ and H2O2 is mixed with the organic effluent which produces HO ⦁ radicals by the following reaction (Eq. 11): (11) Fe 2 + + H 2 O 2 → Fe 3 + + HO ⦁ + O H − Nevertheless, this reaction requires continuous feeding of Fe2+ species for the reaction to be prolonged. In addition, Fe3+ ions react with hydroxide ions to produce insoluble ferric hydroxide precipitates. To tackle this problem, modified Fenton process using UV radiation or solar light is preferred where Fe3+ ions are regenerated to Fe2+ by photoreduction under irradiation with photons having wavelength less than 260 nm. Important advantages of Fenton and photo-Fenton reaction with Fe2+ ions are that it requires a non-complex system, proceeds at ambient conditions, fast reaction rate to generate HO ⦁ , high-efficiency of mineralization of organic compounds and is environmentally non-toxic. Despite all these merits, homogeneous Fenton reaction presents few roadblocks for commercial utilization. Iron-based Fenton reactions proceed in strongly acidic conditions (pH < 3) with a negligible reaction rate noticed in neutral pH. Along with this, non-separable nature of Fe2+ and Fe3+ gives rise to huge iron sludge and non-recyclability of the catalyst, which in turn increases the overall cost of the Fenton reaction [367]. Separable nature of heterogeneous catalyst provides a better alternative to overcome these hurdles to produce HO ⦁ radicals for AOPs. Iron oxides like hematite (α-Fe2O3), maghemite (γ-Fe2O3) and FeOOH are used in the past for Fenton reactions with limited success because Fe3+ reacts with H2O2 almost 3 times slower than Fe2+ when used in homogeneous reactions [368]. Thus, all these iron oxides essentially contain Fe3+ that requires a reductive environment like UV irradiation for the generation of Fe2+ on the surface. In addition, the need for acidic conditions for such reaction accounts for the leaching of Fe ions from the surface of the catalyst, which again results in the increase of secondary pollutants in the form of iron sludge. This leaching can be suppressed by selecting a material that can exhibit catalytic properties for Fenton reaction in neutral pH. At the same time, this catalytic material should acquire multiple oxidation states so that the catalytically active oxidation state can be effectively regenerated from an inactive state by just a simple redox reaction. Both these features are exhibited in cobalt-based oxides, for example Co3O4, which is composed of Co2+ and Co3+ states where active Co2+ species are rejuvenated from Co3+ by reduction reaction under visible light. Most importantly, the Fenton reaction proceeds in a wide pH range (5−9) including neutral pH with cobalt-based species [368]. Even though Co2+ has been found to be the best among transition metals for SO 4 ⦁ − generation, but only a few studies related to Co2+ mediated generation of HO ⦁ radicals are reported. For the oxidative decomposition of acid red 183 and basic blue 9 dye, Ling et al. [369] used the homogeneous system of Co2+/oxone and Co2+/H2O2 for OH- radical production in neutral pH range. Co2+ salt and H2O2 also showed effective oxidation properties under photo-Fenton and electro-Fenton process. However, this homogeneous route involving Co2+ is not recommended for remediation of wastewater owing to the toxic nature of the cobalt element. Thus, heterogeneous catalyst like Co2+ supported over high surface area matrix and Co-oxide (Co3O4) powder and thin film immobilized on the substrate are mostly used for photo-Fenton reaction. Both in homogeneous and heterogeneous reaction pathway, Co2+ species reacts with H2O2 to generate HO ⦁ radicals for oxidation of organic pollutants and Co3+, while Co2+ is regenerated by reaction between Co3+ and H2O2. (12) Co 2 + + H 2 O 2 → Co 3 + + HO ⦁ + O H − (13) Co 3 + + H 2 O 2 → Co 2 + + HO 2 ⦁ + H + (14) Co 3 + + HO 2 ⦁ → Co 2 + + O 2 Pal et al. [370] compared the various transition metals like Co2+, Fe2+, Cu2+, Mn2+, and Ni2+ adsorbed on surfactant-modified alumina for degradation of methyl orange (MO) dye in presence of H2O2 and visible light. In comparison to other metal counterparts, Co2+ displayed the best catalytic activity. During the recycling test, this group showed negligible leaching of cobalt from the support in neutral pH, thus demonstrating the possible commercial application. Similarly, Co2+ supported on a porous support such as MCM-41 [371] and carbon aerogel [372] also showed good performance in the removal of organic pollutants in presence of H2O2.
