Spinel Co3O4 is generally the most preferred form of cobalt-oxide for the oxidation of organic pollutants because of its desired catalytic properties and thermodynamic stability [373,374]. 0D nanoparticles, 1D nanowires, 2D nanoflakes, and 3D hierarchical structure of Co3O4 displayed outstanding activity and selectivity for oxidation of organic pollutants as compared to their bulk counterparts [40,374–378]. This improved activity is attributed to the high surface area, shape- & size-dependent properties and large quantity of under-coordinated active sites on the catalyst surface. Even if either Co2+ is held in porous support [379,380] or fabricated as Co3O4 nanostructures, the final product is still in the form of powder which presents issues related to recovery and reusability, and inability to utilize in continuous flow reactors. Even after centrifugation, these particles exist in water in the form of colloids and thus provides a major drawback. Thus, Co3O4 catalyst in the form of nanoparticles immobilized on a specific substrate with firm adhesion provides the best option to eliminate the problem related to recovery and serve as a reusable environmentally friendly “green-catalyst”. Although Co3O4 thin coating is synthesized by several physical and chemical techniques, only a few were able to form nanostructures of the catalyst on the coating surface with good adhesion. Just recently, through our extensive experimental research work, we illustrated the use of a versatile technique such as PLD in fabricating and tailoring the unique nanostructures with different composition in the form of coatings supported on a glass substrate. In our initial work [40], Co3O4 coating assembled with NPs of an average size of 25 nm was synthesized by PLD in a single step without post-annealing treatment ( Fig. 14a-b). Different set of samples were manufactured by varying the substrate temperature during deposition and it was found that the coating with mixed disordered-nanocrystalline phase of Co3O4 is more effective than the completely crystallized Co3O4 phase for degradation of methylene blue (MB) dye in presence of H2O2 and visible light at neutral pH. On comparing with the same amount of homogeneous catalyst with Co2+ ions, the heterogeneous Co3O4 NPs assembled coating showed significantly higher degradation rate with complete mineralization of MB dye recorded in 240 mins while Co2+ ions were able to remove only 40% (Fig. 14c). The recycling behaviour was reported with little decrease in catalytic activity for Co3O4 NPs assembled coating in the same work. On comparing with Co3O4 coatings produced by other techniques (electron-beam deposition, sol-gel, and electroless) having nearly same particle-like morphology (Fig. 14d-g), PLD deposited Co3O4 coatings illustrated the best photo-degradation rate of dye (Fig. 14 h) as a result of promoting features of nanoparticles with a low degree of agglomeration, narrow size distribution, smaller average size, perfect spherical shape and mixed amorphous-nanocrystalline phase [381]. The versatility of the PLD technique was proved in tailoring the composition and nanostructures of the synthesized Co3O4 NPs by just varying the deposition conditions where single phase to multiphase (Co, CoO, Co3O4) core-shell NPs can be fabricated in a single step [375]. Using Co-B as the target material, core-shell particles were deposited by PLD on the coating surface with metallic cobalt core and shell composed of a mixture of Co, B and O [377]. These core-shell particles under thermal oxidation process at 600 ⁰C transform into hierarchical urchin-like particles composed of Co3O4 nanowires, with the diameter in the range of 30–60 nm and length 1–3 µm, grown radially from the core surface ( Fig. 15a-b). When compared with chemically derived urchin-like Co3O4 particle (Fig. 15c-d) for oxidation of MB dye via photon-Fenton reaction, this physically established nanostructure illustrated 5 times higher degradation rate (Fig. 15e). In reusability tests, the physically grown urchin structure was stable after several cycles while chemically constructed urchin crumbled after the first cycle, thus demonstrating the robust nature of PLD grown Co3O4 catalyst coatings. Similar to the case of SO 4 ⦁ − generation, mixed metal oxides such as spinel cobalt ferrite (CoFe2O4) has been investigated for degradation of organic compounds by photo-Fenton reaction involving H2O2 due to its excellent catalytic activity, stability and separable properties [382,383]. The synergic role played by both Co and Fe in the degradation mechanism resulted in a high degradation rate of dyes as compared to its single metal oxide counterparts. CoFe2O4 being a semiconductor material, when absorbs photons, produces e- and h+ pairs, where photo-generated h+ directly oxidizes OH- to produce HO ⦁ radicals while e- reduces Fe3+ to form Fe2+. The Fe2+ and Co2+ ions react with H2O2 to generate HO ⦁ to increase the overall rate of reaction. Further, due to their enriched magnetic properties, Cao et al. [382] labelled CoFe2O4 as the most promising alternative for the recyclable photo-Fenton catalyst for removing organic dyes. In order to improve the photo-generated charge separation, CoFe2O4 particles were supported on graphene aerogels by a hydrothermal process which also generates high surface area [384]. These hybrid properties led to very high and recyclable photo-Fenton degradation activity for MO dye pollutants. Very recently, a heterojunction of CoFe2O4/CoO was formed in a hierarchical urchin-like structure developed in a coating deposited by PLD [34]. This heterojunction forms a Z-scheme kind of mechanism to facilitate the spatial separation of photo-generated electron-hole pairs. This unique feature allowed the degradation of organic pollutants to proceed not only via photo-Fenton reaction but also through direct photocatalytic reaction in absence of H2O2, with high efficiency. This mixed-oxide catalyst requires half the time to complete the degradation reaction in comparison to similarly grown nanostructures of single-metal oxide counterparts (Co3O4 and Fe2O3). Shen et al. [385] synthesized a series of CoO, Co0.75Cu0.25O, Co0.5Cu0.5O and CuO NPs by thermochemical reaction and tested them as catalysts for the removal of congo red dye in just 60 mins with a nominal H2O2 concentration of 3%. In this case, Co2+ participates in the generation of HO ⦁ radical, whereas Cu2+ reacts with H2O2 to generate superoxide radicals. The by-product of both reactions (Co3+ and Cu+) reacts among themselves to regenerate Co2+ and Cu2+ on the catalyst surface. 5 Synthesis methods Like other classes of catalysts, Co-based catalysts have also been synthesized by various chemical and physical methods. There are a few good reviews that extensively cover the synthesis strategies used for Co and other transition-metal based catalysts [386,387]. Herein, we will not lay too much emphasis on all the synthesis strategies but will try to give the readers a gist of the most widely used methods only. For simplification, the synthesis methods for Co-based compounds are classified into three broad material categories, as discussed below. 5.1 Co oxides and hydroxides Co hydroxides are commonly used as precursors, which are annealed at relevant temperatures to form Co oxides (such as Co3O4). For catalysis, it is often desired to fabricate materials with higher surface area, exposing large number of surface-active centers. To achieve high surface area, Co oxide is prepared in the form of several nanostructures such as nanoflakes [225,388], nanowires [389,390], hollow nansospheres [391,392], nanocubes [393,394], urchin like structures [377,395], etc. Some of the more popular methods to form these nanostructures are solvothermal [396,397], hydrothermal [398], microwave-assisted synthesis [399,400], etc. We synthesized Co3O4 nanostructures using hydrothermal route and observed that changing the Co precursor ions resulted in changes in the morphology [213]. Moreover, similar hydrothermal reactions involve the use of precipitating agents like urea, which lead to the formation of Co hydroxide intermediate phases such as (Co2(OH)2CO3, which decompose on annealing to form the desired Co3O4 phases. Recently, Co3O4 hollow nanotubes was prepared using three routes based on the Kirkendall effect [401]. In this work, the catalyst precipitated by urea was again found to be the most active catalyst with maximum number of active sites. Bai et al. also synthesized 2D and 3D Co3O4 nanostructures using hard template method involving mesoporous silica templates, where 3D Co3O4 structures showed the best catalytic activity [402]. Similar to Co oxide, Co-based LDHs have also been prepared extensively by hydrothermal treatment [403–406]. 5.2 Co based non-oxide compounds Owing to the extreme diversity of non-oxide Co-catalysts, they are prepared by different methods. For instance, amorphous cobalt boride nanoparticles are predominantly synthesized by chemical reduction method where cobalt salts are chemically reduced by NaBH4 [133]. A similar method is also used to deposit nanopowder coatings on substrates using electroless plating/deposition [138,407]. Crystalline cobalt borides can then be obtained by annealing the amorphous structures above their crystallization temperature under inert atmosphere [127,143]. Other methods to fabricate crystalline Co boride includes high energy milling [408], thermal boronization [409], molten salt [410], solid state methathesis [411], etc. To synthesize cobalt phosphide, a popular method involves mixing the cobalt precursor with hypophosphite salt and annealing above 300 ⁰C in protective atmosphere [412,413]. A variation in the method involves chemical vapour deposition where a cobalt source is placed in the downstream of a tubular furnace such that it is thermally reduced and phosphidated from the produced phosphine gas [73,414]. An alternate method is based on using trioctylphosphine as the source of phosphorus in an organic solvent [74,415]. Both these methods lead to the formation of toxic phosphine gas and hence are not desired. A less toxic method includes the use of inorganic phosphates that are reduced at higher temperatures to form cobalt phosphides [416]. Likewise, cobalt nitrides, sulphides and selenides can be synthesized using high temperatures in the presence of nitrogen, sulphur and selenium sources, respectively [95,102,417]. 5.3 Co single atom catalysts For loading single atom catalysts on desired substrates, specific synthesis strategies are devised. As cobalt is not a noble-metal catalyst, it becomes even more difficult to synthesize cobalt-based SACs and keep them in a reduced state. Also, depending upon the desired loading amount, different synthesis methods have to be adopted. For instance, the bottom-up strategy where metal atoms are first adsorbed and then reduced to confine them on the substrate surface, lead to smaller mass loadings (< 1.5%) [418,419]. Wu et al. dispersed ∼15.3% Co SACs on 2D carbon nanosheets through pyrolysis of KCl particles wrapped in Co-based MOF (ZIF-67), followed by carbonization under Ar atmosphere [418]. Zhao et al. stabilized a series of metal SACs including ∼12.1 wt% Co atoms by pyrolyzing Co nitrate precursor with α-D-glucose and melamine at 800 ⁰C under Ar flow [420]. To confine the growth of metal atoms, Wei et al. used a method where the aqueous solution of Co precursor was frozen under liquid nitrogen temperature and then added to the reducing solution at low temperature [421]. As the melting of frozen precursor is very slow, only a few metal ions were released and subsequently reduced to form SACs, thus preventing the growth of particles. In addition to these methods, several other chemical, physical and thermal strategies were used to form Co-based SACs [315,319,422]. 6 Summary and Future Outlook This review emphasizes the significance of Co-based catalysts and reviews their recent advancements in various energy and environment related applications. Co and Co-based catalysts have been predominantly used as low-cost alternatives to replace the industrially used Pt-group catalysts. In water electrolysis, several Co-based compounds (borides, phosphides, chalcogenides) have been discovered as bifunctional electrocatalysts, thus proving useful to catalyze both the half-reactions, i.e HER and OER. This is an important industrial requirement as it cuts down the capital cost of manufacturing two different set of electrodes. Using the same catalyst as anode and cathode of a water electrolyzer also provides an opportunity to switch the polarity of the electrodes periodically, with an aim to clean their surfaces and thus increase the lifetime and efficiency of the electrodes being used. Co-borides have emerged as the most ideal class of electrocatalysts for use in alkali water electrolyzers whereas Co-phosphides and Co- chalcogenides are most effective for use in acidic water electrolyzers. We suggest that the future research in these classes of electrocatalysts must be carried out with an intention to explore their viability in practically relevant systems, such as in membraned electrolyzers. For hydrolysis of chemical hydrides, a great deal of advancement has already been achieved with Co-based catalysts. The biggest achievement has been the development of thin film-based Co-compounds that can be easily upscaled by coating on large surfaces. The bottleneck here lies in the recycling of spent chemical hydrides, which if solved, can provide a great impetus to on-board H2 applications. In the case of CO2RR, it was observed that CoPcs have already been implemented in membrane-based configuration effectively. However, the selectivity of Co-based catalysts in achieving a single product is still limited. It is suggested that more research needs to be carried out in improving the selectivity of Co-based catalysts to make them relevant for commercial applications. Research must also be undertaken to obtain high value products, such as alcohols, using Co-based catalysts, which at present is very limited. We believe that a three-way research involving experimentation, computational studies and in-situ/operando studies must be adopted to gain new breakthroughs in CO2RR using Co-based catalysts. Heterogeneous supported Co-based catalyst offers the best solution for AOP based remediation of wastewater from organic pollutants with high activity, stability and recyclability. This not only ensures the minimum leaching of catalyst but also make AOPs more environmentally friendly and cost-effective. Although the technical aspects are well covered in the various reports about the Co catalyst, but the mechanism involving the generation of ROS ( SO 4 ⦁ − and HO ⦁ ) on the Co surface to realize the role of the Co active sites is still not clear. The role of supports holding the Co species also need to be investigated thoroughly to understand the synergic effect created between them to enhance the catalytic activity and inhibit the leaching of cobalt in the reaction solution. In a nutshell, cobalt and its derivatives have truly become an indispensable part of the catalysis community. Despite the promise that it presents towards replacing noble metal catalysts, it must not be forgotten that cobalt is already in the European Union’s list of critical raw materials, suggesting that its availability can be a real challenge in the coming future. Moreover, there are a few reports that also show concern about the health hazards of cobalt [423,424]. Thus, it is recommended that all uses of cobalt must be monitored closely to ensure no direct release in the environment, especially water sources. Some efforts are also needed to understand the effect of cobalt toxicity, especially from spent catalysts on biological life forms, with an aim to understand the true risks and design mitigation measures. This can be achieved through life cycle analysis for each catalytic application. To keep a tab on the toxicity and cost of cobalt-based catalysts, future research must be focused with a view to improve the specific properties relevant to the desired reactions. For instance, the catalytic activity per site of cobalt catalyst must be improved to facilitate better catalyst utilization. A better understanding of the cobalt surface chemistry will go a long way in designing purposeful catalysts. This can be achieved by modern analytical in-situ/operando tools, supported by theoretical and machine learning-based computational tools. Nevertheless, it is suggested that the research in Co-based materials must be continued with greater enthusiasm as they have the potential to achieve new benchmarks in multiple areas of catalysis. These materials are expected to play key roles in realizing a sustainable society by fulfilling our needs for renewable energy and enriching the environment. coredata.dc:description: In a bid to tackle the degrading climate conditions, the new age research in catalysis is predominantly focused on sustainable technologies associated with renewable energy conversion and environment purification. One of the primary motivations for the research in catalysis is the use of low-cost, earth-abundant materials that can fulfill the scale-up needs of respective technologies. Cobalt (Co) based catalysts have been an indispensable part of almost all areas of catalysis and they are often looked at as low-cost substitutes for precious metal-based catalysts. In the context of energy and environmental applications, Co-based catalysts are more commonly used for reactions such as hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), oxygen evolution reaction (OER), hydrolysis of chemical hydrides, CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) and advanced oxidation processes (AOPs). Co-based catalysts are interesting compounds as Co plays a diverse role in facilitating different reactions. This review provides a brief account of the significance of Co-based catalysts and elaborates their advancement in each of the above-mentioned applications and presents future research directions with the use of Co-based catalysts. An in-depth analysis to gain a deeper understanding of the Co-based systems is highly desired to promote breakthroughs in catalysis.

coredata.dc:title: A review of cobalt-based catalysts for sustainable energy and environmental applications
